Literature Review: Polar metals have been a subject of interest for decades, with the first proposal of their existence dating back to the 1970s. The concept of polar metals, where both polarity and metallicity coexist in the same phase, has garnered significant attention in recent years due to the discovery of the first polar metallic compounds, LiOsO3 and WTe2 (1, 2). These materials have opened a new paradigm in polar metal research, with implications in various fields such as topology, ferroelectricity, magnetoelectricity, spintronics, and superconductivity (3, 4). The availability of polar metallic samples has enabled researchers to explore their unique properties and develop new techniques for designing and engineering these materials (5, 6). In this review, we will discuss the principles and techniques that have been developed to create polar metals, their interesting properties, and the most promising directions for future work.
